newsitem.title: RUSSIA: Conservative agrarian sees low Russian harvest.
newsitem.headline: Conservative agrarian sees low Russian harvest.

text.p: Interfax news agency quoted a conservative agrarian politician as saying on Thursday that Russia's total grain harvest this year may be 12 to 15 million tonnes below official forecasts of 75-77 million tonnes.
Nikolai Kharitonov, head of the Agrarian Party faction in parliament, was quoted as saying the slow pace of harvesting in Siberia and a lack of farming equipment stood behind his grim forecast.
The Agrarians support a return of the farming sector to state control.
The State Statistics Committee (Goskomstat) said on Wednesday that as of Monday, Russia had gathered 58.2 million tonnes of grain, 4.2 million more than at the same date last year.
But farmers still have to harvest some 12.7 million hectares of grain including 10.7 million in the Siberian and Urals regions.
Kharitonov said that less than 10 percent of the total area sown to grain in Siberia had so far been harvested and each combine had to cover 350-400 hectares, or three times the optimal area.
Interfax quoted the Agriculture Ministry as saying that by Monday, farmers in Western Siberia had harvested 1.5 million tonnes against 3.2 million tonnes at the same date last year.
It said the grain harvest in Eastern Siberia was faring better and was so far at 487,000 tonnes compared to 417,000 tonnes in 1995. --Dmitry Solovyov, Moscow Newsroom, +7095 941 8520
